principle: The authoring tool user interface follows applicable accessibility guidelines

guidelines.name: Web-based functionality is accessible
guidelines.description: The full editing experience conforms to WCAG 2.0 (or other accessibility guidelines).

guidelines.name: Non-web-based functionality is accessible
guidelines.description: If the interface is not on the web, it conforms to platform-specific accessibility guidelines.

guidelines.name: Alternative content available to editors
guidelines.description: If there is anything visible that is not text, like icons, images or video, there is alternative text available.

guidelines.name: Editing-view presentation can be programmatically determined
guidelines.description: Status indicators (like changes or spelling errors) and text properties (like italics or bold) are conveyed to users of assistive technologies.

guidelines.name: Works with keyboard
guidelines.description: Everything that can be done with a mouse, can just as easily be done with a keyboard, including drag and drop and drawing capabilities. There should be no keyboard traps. Keyboard usage should be efficient and easier to use than just with sequential access (for example: use WAI-ARIA landmarks or offer keyboard shortcuts).

guidelines.name: Enough time
guidelines.description: Time limits in the editor, like for auto-save, can be turned off or extended (some exceptions apply).

guidelines.name: Flashing content optional
guidelines.description: Flashing content, like videos, including previews of that kind of content, can be paused or turned off.

guidelines.name: Content can be navigated by structure
guidelines.description: Users can navigate quicker by structure, for example headings, lists or HTML elements.

guidelines.name: Content searchable
guidelines.description: Users can search in text content, results are focused when shown. If there are no matches, this is indicated. User can search in two directions (backwards and forwards).

guidelines.name: Supports display preferences
guidelines.description: If there are user settings for display, this only affects the editing view, not the output. If a content editor uses OS settings like high contrast mode or their own stylesheet, this does not break the editing experience.

guidelines.name: Previews are accessible
guidelines.description: When the tool shows a preview of the content, that preview is at least as accessible as in current browsers and other user agents.

guidelines.name: Helps editor prevent and correct mistakes
guidelines.description: Lets users undo changes and settings.

guidelines.name: (Accessibility) features documented
guidelines.description: Documents all features, including accessibility features.
